grafton aal settlement here. We have appealed
TO their native justice and magnanimity, and
we hav conjured them by the ties Of our COM
mon kindred TO disavow these usurpations, which
would inevitably interrupt our connexions and
correspondence. They too have been deaf to
the voice of justice and consanguinity, We
must therefore, acquiescc in the necessity which
denounces our separation, and hold them, as we
hold the rest of mankind nd--cncmics in war, in
in peace friends.


We, Therefore, the representatives of the U.
nited States of America, in general Cong ress as
sembed, appealing to the Supreme Judge Of the
world, for the rcctitude of intentions, do, in
the name and by the authority Of the good pco-
Pile Of these colonies, solemnly publish AMI de-
clare, that these United Colonies arc, and oiright
ought to be, free and Independent States that
they are absolved from all allegiance to the Brit
ish crown, and that all political connexion be-
tween them and the state of Great Britain, is,
and ought to be, totally dissolved; and that as
free and Independent states, they have tullpow-
er to levy war, conclude peace contract alliances,
establish commerce, and to 10 all other acts and
things VIII ch independent states may oirigh. do.
And for the support Of this declaration, with "A
firm reliance on the protection of Divine Irovi
dence, we mutually pledge to each othe' our
lives, our fortunes, and our sacred honor


JOHN HANCOCK, PrSidod

NOTICE.

At very numerous ana respectable
meeting of the citizens of the State OF
Delaware, friendly to Manufactures and Ag-
riculture, convened by public notice, at the
Town Hall, in Wilmington, 9Th Mo. 9th,
Kensey Johns, Esq. was called to the chair,
and Joseph e. Rowland was appointed Sec
retary.


The following resolutions were then adopt
ed,


| Reso{ued, That the protection of Ameri-
can manufactures, by a judicious tariff is, in
the opinion Of this meeting, the true and OBJ
rious policy of this nation; that the truth Of
this proposition is every day demonstrated
by the tlourIshing condition of every portion
of our country where manufacturing estab-
lishments are in successful progressna con-
dition not confined to the manufacturer him
self, but participated in by every other
branch OF industry within the sphere of its
influence, and especially by the Farmer
thus exhibiting the intimate union subsisting
between the two great interests of agricul-
ture and manufactures; and that while we
cordially approve ofthe policy, we entertain
no doubht Of the constitutional power Of
Congress to legislate upon subject, which
was deemed peculiar object OF their care
by Washington, Jefferson, Madison and Mon
roe; and upon which Congress has exercis
ed the right of legislation from the origin of
the government to the present day.
ReSoiUed, That we regard the doctrine
contained in the proceedings recently pro
mulgated by the legislature of Virginia, de-
nying to Congress any power whatever to
protect any domestic manufactures, as fall
lacious and visionary in the extreme-as
! contrary to the best interests and happiness
Of the nation, as it is repugnant to the true
intention and correct exposition of the in
strument it assumes to interpret-contra
dicted by the concurring opinion OF the ia
theirs of the Constitution itself, OF Washing
ton. Hamilton, and Madison. and by the uni
form practice Of every admiration which had
acted under that Constitution.


Reselved, That we approve the bill which
passed the House Of Representatives during
the last session of Congress, entitled "An act
for the alteration Of the acts imposing duties
ON imposts." We regard it as measure pc
culiarly calculated to promote the interest Of
the agrculturalist and the manufacturer, By
the protection it secured to the manu-
facturer OF coarse woollens and to the pro-
duce of the raw material.


1t protected the manufacturer, not by ma.
terially increasing the duty, but by fixing
the value in such manner as to defeat the
frauds and evasons, by which the revenue
had been diminished and the manufacturer
oppressed.


1t protected and encouraged the growth OF
wool, by an increase of duty on the foreign
material so gradual as to keep pace with the
gradual increase of the means of production


RESOLVED. That this meeting cordially ac-
cept the invitation Of the Pennsylvania So
ciety of Manufactures and the Mechanic
Arts, to appoint delegation to attend
general convention at Harrisburg on the 3oth
day of July next, for the purpose of deliber-
ating on the measures proper to be taken in
the present "depressed state of the wooden
manufacture and of the market for WOOL"
and such other manufactures as require le-
gisative encouragement, and that HcnryM
Ridgley, Louis M'Lane," f. I. Dupont, las
Candy, James r. Black, Doct. A Naudain,
VIM. w. Young, and Caleb Kirk, be ap.
pointed delegates for this purpose.


Resolved, That ifany of the delegates ar-
pointed by this meeting to attend the con
vention at Harrisburg, decline going, their
place may be filled by the selection of an
other individual by the remaining delegates
| Resolved, That the proceeding of this
! meeting be signed by the chairman and sec
retary. and published in the public papers


K.JOHNS. Chairman.


JIG. ROWLAND, Secretary.

Remarking on the universal abundance
which promises this year to reward ruralla-
Dor throughout this happy land, the Editor
of the Petersburg Republican offers the fol-
lowing just and honorable suggestion: SIN
contemplating the prospect of abundance be.
fore US, we would address the husbandmen
of our land in the glowing language of the
eloquent Thompson, and say to them:-


tThink, oh! grateful think!


How good the God Of harvest is to you;
Who pours abundance DER your flowing fields"

Granville Sharp Pattison, has. in conse.
quence of illhealth. resigned his proffer-
ship in the Maryland University.

Marry DEPARTMENT


June 25th, 1897.
The President of the United States has
approved the following General Regulations:
l. No person who is less than fourteen
years old will be appointed a Midshipman.
2. Midshipmen ofthe age of twenty years.
who have been five years in service, and
performed active duty at sea for three years,
will be entitled to be examined tor promo
ton. II found qualified, they will be rank
ed as Passed Midshipmen."


3. Those who have been twice examined
and rejected, or have twice received notice to
attend an examination, and have declined,
will be dismissed.


4. Passed Midshipmen will receive War
rants as such---will take rank of all other
Midshipmen, and receive the pay oftwenty-
tlve dollars per month, and two rations per
day. SAMUEL L. SOUTHARD.
WASHINGTON, June 90.

ton, yesterday, with more hustle and parade,
than we have witnessed for length of
time. Nodding plumes and glittering bayo.
nets have been rare sights with us during
these piping times OF peace" but when we
hear the merry tap of the drum, the martial
impulse is irresistible. We thought the
martial spirit of our peaceable borough
had become extinct since the late war, as
one fourth Of July after another passed a
way without the least display Of military pa
rade; but in this we were mistaken. for the
wild ambition of some Of our legislators,
who, painting for the glory of commanding
a batch of cornstalks and hoop-poles, induc-
ed them to pass military law, that the good
citizens of the state Of Delaware might be
dragged indiscriminately, four times year,
into the field through dust and mud to wit
ness the admirable feats of their gallant Of
flccrs. But to return to sketch Of the events
of the day:


We suppose our readers at distance, and
particularly those who have been kept at
home BY the labours of the harvest field,
would like to know what kind Of day we
had.


On Tuesday evening, the two volunteer
companies, State Fenei6ics and Washington
Grays, commanded by Captains Porter and
MClung, paraded in fine style and repaired
to the Old Ferry, about half mile below
the borough to receive the Washington Fen
cibirS, Capt. Cooper, from Philadelphia, who
were expected to join US in commemorating
the great day. The steamboat arrived about
6 o'clock, and the troops expected, having
discmbarked, were received by those in
waiting, and escorted up to town under the
command of Major Woolfe. In the eyening
our welcomed yisiters enjoyed pleasant ex-
curslon upon the romantic shores of the
brandy wine, the beauties of the scenery be !.


ing heightened by the ia! OF bright moon.


On the morning Of the 4th, about O'Clock,
the drums beat to arms. The respective
companies met and repaired to shady
grove about a mile west of the town, where
they partook of plain but substantial colla-
ton. The Declaration of Independence was
read and many patriotic toast drank, and
had it not been for two unpleasant circum-
stances, the hilarities Of thl day would have
ended in most agreeable manner; one Of
which was tremendous gust of rain, which
came upon the company about the time
they we're preparing to return to town,
which drenched every mothers son of them
to the very skin. and they, poor fellows. came
home in most unenviable predicament.
The other circumstance to which we alludc,
nance. was ola most serious nature-and we arc
not certain that the result will not be the loss Of
the lives Of two of our citizens. These young
men were engaged with others in loading and fir
ing field piece which was used to respond the
sentiments of the tousts which were drank, and
were in the act of ramming home heavy car.
fridge, when the gun went off. The result may
almost Immediately be conceived. Roth per.
sons were blown several feet from the mue-e OF
the gun and most prcadfuly mangled. One of
them, Mr.. w. Hyatt, had his right hand blown
off and was otherways much injured in face and
body, by the powder, the oher, Tarrans Brady,
was more dangerously injured, having the from
tai hone of his head shattered considerably; one
eve blown out, and his face and neck tlreadfuly
mangletl-but little hopes are entertained of his
recovery The fractured part Of Mr.. Ilyatt's
arm was amputated, and hop are entertained
that he will do well.


This morning our Philadelphia friends were
escorted to the steamboat Superior, On hoard of
which they embarked to return to their native
city, bearing with them the warmest wishes Of
our citizens, for safe passage. Capt. Cooper's
Company was composed Of fine looking young
men, handsomely uniformed and well discipln-
ed, and their department whilst with rs was
such as to engage our warnest feelings of re-
spect and admiration. Less cannot be said Of
our own troops; young, vigorous and full Of mar.
tial pride, they cndcavorcd to excel in this, to
its admirers, fascinating sciences and so great is
their improvement in.discipline, that one would
suppose they had been, instead of u few weeks
rgidly drilled for years Their general appear
ance is highly creditable.

A case of novelty and extraordinary interest
occupied the Mayors Court all Thursday last. -
Thomas Clark, a young man OF handsome APP
pearance, about "a years ofaSe, lis hair and face
looking especially sleek and smooth, by occu-
patton shoemaker, and by profession fanatic,
was tried under on old act Of Assembly, for
speaking wilf,llly, dcspitetnly, and lsrespcct-
fully of the Almighty. The Indictment charg-
cs him with saying and repeating at divers times
and places, 81 AN Godt"


1t tappearcd that Clark profcsscd a smattcr ng
of the school OF Toannas Snuthcote and Jcmima
Wilkinson, representing himself to be divine,
not in his origin, but in his nilsson and powers.
lie has been for months surround d in this city
by forty or fifty women and delldcl men, who
are fools enough to believe hi, pleposterous pro-
fcssions These he classiics as his disciples, and
gives to them all his pretended powers They
believe him to possess the faculty Of working
miracles, and many of them s~ore in open court,
that he had actually performed them; such as
making the dumb to speak; the sick well; and
the Blind TO sec. CLARK and his followers call
themselves .erastcrs." Clark himself has been
for some time generally known among the idle
bows of his vicinity, as 1om Cldrk


Judge Read charged the jury to acqnit for
want Of wilful malice. that Clark was weak
foolish fanatic, doing all he did nnocently, and
being more misguided and silly than criminal
more an object Of pity than punishment.


Clark addressed the court and jury for long
time. lie had the scriptures in his hand, from
which he quoted willy and copously. His
speech was little else than citations otpassaSes.

S,eam Cayriace.-An extraordinary sensation
: was created on Thursday evening, IN the ncign-
borhood of the Regents Park, by the sudden


appearance Of (iuerney's newly invented steam
, carriage, or selfmovng machine, winch coursea


round part of the new road up the ascent OF the


Albany road, at the rate of ten miles an hour,
/. carving several persons inside and behind 1t


seemed to move with the most perfect ease, and
: without any appearance OF smoke whatever.-


The condt.cfeur evidently held the carriage tin-
/ der complete command; and whenever the crowd


which gathered about it became troublesome,
shooting away from them with speed equal to
that of a mail coach.--London O6Serrer.

A friend relates to us the following instance of
canine sagacity; Mr.. Joseph Hanson resides on
the Pinkham road in the county of Coos, near
Mount Washington, eight miles from any inhab-
liant. Ills child was lately taken dangerously
sck--so that neither himself nor his wife could
safely leave without assistance. Enclosing a
letter in a packet, he despatched his dog ten
miles to the house Of Mr.. Pinkham; and the dog
delivered the message in an hour and half, so
that in the course Of few hoursthc necessary as.
sistance arrived When the dog arrived at Ad-
ans among the inhabitants, he passed several
persons, and cvaded them, as if fearful that he
should be prevented from doing his duty.

A land Tortoise was lately found on the
farm of Mr.. Randolph, near Meadville, Pa.
with the letters IF. H." cut on the lower
shell. said to have Been done b. Frederick
Haymaker, in 1894. being SO years ago. 1t
was found On the same farm about 20, and
again about "a years ago. The letters II.
A. 1897" have been added.

A gentleman from Southington has furnished
us with the particulars of an accident, the reci-
al which will, we trust, operate as a salutary
caution TO parents, while it awakens the deepest
feelings Of sympathy for the distressed mother.
On Sunday, the 18th ult little child besought
its mother for knife; after some importantly,
she allowed it to take the instrument. The
child then begged to have it opened; the moth.
er mprudenty opened it, and passed out of the
room, In moment, she heard her infant cream
returned ard b held it corpse! The knife
was sharp pointed, and the child stumbled and
fell upon it with such force, that it entered the
left side, and pierced the heart.

brought in he Ipest Indies. Captain KNAPP. Of
the Mary Jane, at Newburyport, from St. Pier
res reports that there never was SO dry season
before known, in Martinique; not drop of rain
had descended for more than six weeks and ve-
getatlon was entirely parched up; the planters
were in despalI-the cane cut was but one third
grown-they asked 40 sous for molasses on the
estates, and there would be but little at that
price. The Mary Jane waited 50 daysand could
procure but 5000 gallons

The following anecdotc is given il Par


is paper, as received from country cores
pondeni:.-About twenty years ago young
man, violently in loye with young Provin-
cial, not being able to obtain the consent Of
her family to their union, he enlisted as
soldier. In the campaign of 1921, he was
taken prisoner by the Russians. and sent in
to Siberia, whence he escaped, and joined
horde of 'rartars, then at war with China
He was second time made prisoner; but,
more fortunate than in his first captivity, he
insinuated himself into the good graces OF
his conquerors, and gradually rose to the
dignity of a Mandarin. His affection .did not
however change with his good fortune; he
despatched vessel to Europe to convey the
object Of his first love to China; this vessel
has lust arrived at Marseiles. and will re-
turn as soon as the object of its mission shall
have been executed.

FROM LAGUlRA.-A slip from the
New York Mercantile, says-We learn by
the Eclipse, which left Lagura on the 9th
inst, that Bolivar remained at Caracas, and
Il vas not known when he would depart tor
the interior.
"A letter from Laguira, of the Sd, says.
ave have intelligence, that by direction OF
the executive, all the guns and ammunition
in the different forts of Porto Cavelo, have
been removed, and that the only castle now
remaining i'll that place. is to be demolish- :
ed. The object of these proceedings is quite
unknown to us. 1t is reported here. that the
Congress has accepted the resignation Of
Bolivar.


The following extract is from Mr.. Bddle's
culogium on Jefferson -


"Thrre lies in the depths of every heart
that dream of youth, and the chastened WISH
of manhood, which neither cares nor hon
ors can ever extinguish, the hope OF one day
resting from the pursuits which aosoro US;
OF interposing between our old age and the
tomb-soine tranquil interval of refiect'on'
when with feelings not subdued but soften
ed, with passions not exhausted but mel
lowed. we may look calmly on the past with
out regret, and ON the future without appre-
hension. But in the tumult OF the world
this vision for ever recedes as we approach
it; the passions which have asitated oui

full articles.article:
grafton aal settlement here. We have appealed
TO their native justice and magnanimity, and
we hav conjured them by the ties Of our COM
mon kindred TO disavow these usurpations, which
would inevitably interrupt our connexions and
correspondence. They too have been deaf to
the voice of justice and consanguinity, We
must therefore, acquiescc in the necessity which
denounces our separation, and hold them, as we
hold the rest of mankind nd--cncmics in war, in
in peace friends.


We, Therefore, the representatives of the U.
nited States of America, in general Cong ress as
sembed, appealing to the Supreme Judge Of the
world, for the rcctitude of intentions, do, in
the name and by the authority Of the good pco-
Pile Of these colonies, solemnly publish AMI de-
clare, that these United Colonies arc, and oiright
ought to be, free and Independent States that
they are absolved from all allegiance to the Brit
ish crown, and that all political connexion be-
tween them and the state of Great Britain, is,
and ought to be, totally dissolved; and that as
free and Independent states, they have tullpow-
er to levy war, conclude peace contract alliances,
establish commerce, and to 10 all other acts and
things VIII ch independent states may oirigh. do.
And for the support Of this declaration, with "A
firm reliance on the protection of Divine Irovi
dence, we mutually pledge to each othe' our
lives, our fortunes, and our sacred honor


JOHN HANCOCK, PrSidod


Attest. CH,nLEs Thomson, Sec'y.

Rauardof Nodfrn Put.iciism. Sentence has
been pronounced at New-Orcans, upon the Off
GERS and crew Of the soop Bolvarwho had been

MARINE oiiccr, Gout'e, three years. the other Of

excepting one sailor who on account Of some
mitigating circumstances WAS sent for three
months.

full articles.headline: PUBLIC MEETING.
full articles.article:
At very numerous ana respectable
meeting of the citizens of the State OF
Delaware, friendly to Manufactures and Ag-
riculture, convened by public notice, at the
Town Hall, in Wilmington, 9Th Mo. 9th,
Kensey Johns, Esq. was called to the chair,
and Joseph e. Rowland was appointed Sec
retary.


The following resolutions were then adopt
ed,


| Reso{ued, That the protection of Ameri-
can manufactures, by a judicious tariff is, in
the opinion Of this meeting, the true and OBJ
rious policy of this nation; that the truth Of
this proposition is every day demonstrated
by the tlourIshing condition of every portion
of our country where manufacturing estab-
lishments are in successful progressna con-
dition not confined to the manufacturer him
self, but participated in by every other
branch OF industry within the sphere of its
influence, and especially by the Farmer
thus exhibiting the intimate union subsisting
between the two great interests of agricul-
ture and manufactures; and that while we
cordially approve ofthe policy, we entertain
no doubht Of the constitutional power Of
Congress to legislate upon subject, which
was deemed peculiar object OF their care
by Washington, Jefferson, Madison and Mon
roe; and upon which Congress has exercis
ed the right of legislation from the origin of
the government to the present day.
ReSoiUed, That we regard the doctrine
contained in the proceedings recently pro
mulgated by the legislature of Virginia, de-
nying to Congress any power whatever to
protect any domestic manufactures, as fall
lacious and visionary in the extreme-as
! contrary to the best interests and happiness
Of the nation, as it is repugnant to the true
intention and correct exposition of the in
strument it assumes to interpret-contra
dicted by the concurring opinion OF the ia
theirs of the Constitution itself, OF Washing
ton. Hamilton, and Madison. and by the uni
form practice Of every admiration which had
acted under that Constitution.


Reselved, That we approve the bill which
passed the House Of Representatives during
the last session of Congress, entitled "An act
for the alteration Of the acts imposing duties
ON imposts." We regard it as measure pc
culiarly calculated to promote the interest Of
the agrculturalist and the manufacturer, By
the protection it secured to the manu-
facturer OF coarse woollens and to the pro-
duce of the raw material.


1t protected the manufacturer, not by ma.
terially increasing the duty, but by fixing
the value in such manner as to defeat the
frauds and evasons, by which the revenue
had been diminished and the manufacturer
oppressed.


1t protected and encouraged the growth OF
wool, by an increase of duty on the foreign
material so gradual as to keep pace with the
gradual increase of the means of production


RESOLVED. That this meeting cordially ac-
cept the invitation Of the Pennsylvania So
ciety of Manufactures and the Mechanic
Arts, to appoint delegation to attend
general convention at Harrisburg on the 3oth
day of July next, for the purpose of deliber-
ating on the measures proper to be taken in
the present "depressed state of the wooden
manufacture and of the market for WOOL"
and such other manufactures as require le-
gisative encouragement, and that HcnryM
Ridgley, Louis M'Lane," f. I. Dupont, las
Candy, James r. Black, Doct. A Naudain,
VIM. w. Young, and Caleb Kirk, be ap.
pointed delegates for this purpose.


Resolved, That ifany of the delegates ar-
pointed by this meeting to attend the con
vention at Harrisburg, decline going, their
place may be filled by the selection of an
other individual by the remaining delegates
| Resolved, That the proceeding of this
! meeting be signed by the chairman and sec
retary. and published in the public papers


K.JOHNS. Chairman.


JIG. ROWLAND, Secretary.

A special meeting of The Delaware dead.
e,ny ef Natural science. will be held in the
library room at the Town. Hall, on Friday
next, at o'clock, when an address will be
delivered.


RIA. HENDERSON, Sec'ry.
Wilmington, July S.


Iae Curators are now prepared to re.
ceive donations of specimens Of the Cabinet
tor the Academy.

Remarking on the universal abundance
which promises this year to reward ruralla-
Dor throughout this happy land, the Editor
of the Petersburg Republican offers the fol-
lowing just and honorable suggestion: SIN
contemplating the prospect of abundance be.
fore US, we would address the husbandmen
of our land in the glowing language of the
eloquent Thompson, and say to them:-


tThink, oh! grateful think!


How good the God Of harvest is to you;
Who pours abundance DER your flowing fields"

life disturb our latest hour; and we go down
to the tomb. like the sun into the ocean,
with no gentle and gradual Withdrawing of
the light Of life back to the source which
gave it, but, sullen in its beamless descent,
with all its fiery glow, long after it has lost
its power and its splendor."

full articles.headline: WASHINGTON, June 90.
full articles.article:
Marry DEPARTMENT


June 25th, 1897.
The President of the United States has
approved the following General Regulations:
l. No person who is less than fourteen
years old will be appointed a Midshipman.
2. Midshipmen ofthe age of twenty years.
who have been five years in service, and
performed active duty at sea for three years,
will be entitled to be examined tor promo
ton. II found qualified, they will be rank
ed as Passed Midshipmen."


3. Those who have been twice examined
and rejected, or have twice received notice to
attend an examination, and have declined,
will be dismissed.


4. Passed Midshipmen will receive War
rants as such---will take rank of all other
Midshipmen, and receive the pay oftwenty-
tlve dollars per month, and two rations per
day. SAMUEL L. SOUTHARD.

full articles.article:
nth
ho laws Of Nature and Of Natures God enitle
hsn. a decent respect to the opinions OF man
sa requires that they should declare the causes
l,, impel them to the separations.


". hold these truths TO be sell evident ;
~, all men are created equal, that they are en-
lnwed by their Creator with certain u!aliehabic
INNS that among these are life, liberty, and
,n. nursuit ofhappincss. That to secure these
,rta,s. governments are Instituted among men,
netryor their lust powers from the consent OF
.hs royerned that whenever any form oigov-
e-,n,cnt becomes destructive OF these ends, II
hc right of the people to alter or to abolish 1t,
and to Institute new government laying ITS foun-
Jltiun on such principles, and organizing us
,owers in such form as to them shall seem most
likely to effect their safety and happiness. Pru-
,ence, indeed, will dictate, that governments
onr established should not be changed tor hight
and transient causes and accordingly all expe-
aencc hath shown, that mankind are more dis
,Osed to suffer while evils are suflerable, than
b right themselves BY abolisiing the forms to
ghch they are accustoincd-but when al long
train Of abuses and us'lrpatiDns, pursuing lnvatia-
tly the same oblcc', csinces design TO reduce
item under absolute de1poism, II IS Their right,
is their duty 70 thraw oil such government,
ana to provd. ncw guards for their future sccu-
rty. Such has been the patient sil'ierance Of
Aese colonies and such is now the necessity
which constrains thcln to alter their former sys.
tens of government. The history Of the pres.
cit king of Great Britain, is a history Of repeated
INJURIES and usurn ,tions, all having in direct OBJ
yct the establishment Of an absolute tyranny
aver these states. To prove this let facts be
Submitted to a candid world.
. He has rcf cd hi, assent 10 laws the most
wholesome and necessary for the pubic good.
a N taty nj
immediate and pressing importance, unless sn'-
pended in their operation, ill his assent shonll
"a obtained. and when SO suspended, nc has Mt
,arly neglected to attend to them. He has re-
used to pass other laws for the accommodation
large districts Of people, unless those people
youli rclnqiish the right of representation i'll the
egislature-a right incstlmaLlc to them, and for
uidable to tyran,s only.


He has called together legislative bodies at
places unusual uncomfortable, and distant from
tie repository OF their public records, for the
:olc purpose Of fatiguing them into compliance
with his measures.


lie has dis, ulved representative houses re-
peatedly, for opposing with manly frmness,
bis invSsions on the rights Of the people.


lie has refused, for long time after such
dssolutons, to cause others to be elected !,
whereby the legislative powers, incapable ofan-
Inhalation, have returned to the people at large,
for their exercise, the state remaining, in the
mean time, exposed to all the dangers of invx-
sion from without, and convulsions within.
He has cndeavored to prevent the population
ofthese States; for that purpose obstructng the
laws for naturalization Of foreigners; refusing to
pass others, to encourage their migration hither,
and raising the conditions Of new approp prations
Ct lands


He has obstructed the administration Of Justice,
BY refusing his assent to laws for establishing ju-
dietary powers.


He has made judges dependent on his viii
alone, for the tenure of their Offices and the a.
mount and payment Of their salaries.


lie has erected multitude of new Offices. and
sent hher swarms OF officers, to harass our peo.
pie, and eat out their substance.


He has kept among us, IN times of peace
sanding armies without the consent OF our legis-
htures.


He has affected to render the military indie.
pendent of, and superior to, the civil power.


lie has combined with Others to subject us tc
alursdiction foreign to Our constitution, and un
acknowledged by our laws; giving his assent tc
their acts of pretended legislation


For quartering large bodies of armed troop.
among us


tFor protecting them, by mock trial, from pun
hhment for any murders which they should com
nit on the inhabitants of these states.


For cutting off our trade with all parts of the
world,


For imposing taxes on us without Our consent


For dcprlying us, i'll many cases, OF the bene
ts of'rlal by jury;


For transporting us beyond seas to be tried fol
pretended otfences


For abolishing the free system of English
Jaws in neighboring province, establishing there
~ an arbitrary government, and enlargng it:
boundaries, so as to render it at once an exam
pc and tit itinsrument for introducing the same
sosoute rule into these colonies:


tor taking away our charters, abolshing our
most valuable laws and altering fundamentally
Ne forms Of our governments


for slspending our own legislatures, and de-
.Isflns themselves invested with power to leg
Sate for us in all cases whatsoever.


lie has abdicated government here, by de
caring us out Of his protection, and waging
Warasainst us.


Ournt our towns, and destroyed the lives Of Tho
people.


lie eisat this time transporting large armies o
mnteisn mercenaries to complete the works o
assse', desolaton, and tyranny, already begun
@''h circumstances of cruelty and pertidy, scarce


psfaileled in the most barbarous ages, ane
"Ialy unworthy the head Of civilized nation


ne ne mas constrained our fellow citizens, taker
tpuVe on the high seas; to bear arms agains
,hs sn country, to become the eXecutioners o
hn =, friends and brethren, or to fall themselve.
W their hands.


:, ne has excited domestic instructions amongs,
hnC =.

ton, yesterday, with more hustle and parade,
than we have witnessed for length of
time. Nodding plumes and glittering bayo.
nets have been rare sights with us during
these piping times OF peace" but when we
hear the merry tap of the drum, the martial
impulse is irresistible. We thought the
martial spirit of our peaceable borough
had become extinct since the late war, as
one fourth Of July after another passed a
way without the least display Of military pa
rade; but in this we were mistaken. for the
wild ambition of some Of our legislators,
who, painting for the glory of commanding
a batch of cornstalks and hoop-poles, induc-
ed them to pass military law, that the good
citizens of the state Of Delaware might be
dragged indiscriminately, four times year,
into the field through dust and mud to wit
ness the admirable feats of their gallant Of
flccrs. But to return to sketch Of the events
of the day:


We suppose our readers at distance, and
particularly those who have been kept at
home BY the labours of the harvest field,
would like to know what kind Of day we
had.


On Tuesday evening, the two volunteer
companies, State Fenei6ics and Washington
Grays, commanded by Captains Porter and
MClung, paraded in fine style and repaired
to the Old Ferry, about half mile below
the borough to receive the Washington Fen
cibirS, Capt. Cooper, from Philadelphia, who
were expected to join US in commemorating
the great day. The steamboat arrived about
6 o'clock, and the troops expected, having
discmbarked, were received by those in
waiting, and escorted up to town under the
command of Major Woolfe. In the eyening
our welcomed yisiters enjoyed pleasant ex-
curslon upon the romantic shores of the
brandy wine, the beauties of the scenery be !.


ing heightened by the ia! OF bright moon.


On the morning Of the 4th, about O'Clock,
the drums beat to arms. The respective
companies met and repaired to shady
grove about a mile west of the town, where
they partook of plain but substantial colla-
ton. The Declaration of Independence was
read and many patriotic toast drank, and
had it not been for two unpleasant circum-
stances, the hilarities Of thl day would have
ended in most agreeable manner; one Of
which was tremendous gust of rain, which
came upon the company about the time
they we're preparing to return to town,
which drenched every mothers son of them
to the very skin. and they, poor fellows. came
home in most unenviable predicament.
The other circumstance to which we alludc,
nance. was ola most serious nature-and we arc
not certain that the result will not be the loss Of
the lives Of two of our citizens. These young
men were engaged with others in loading and fir
ing field piece which was used to respond the
sentiments of the tousts which were drank, and
were in the act of ramming home heavy car.
fridge, when the gun went off. The result may
almost Immediately be conceived. Roth per.
sons were blown several feet from the mue-e OF
the gun and most prcadfuly mangled. One of
them, Mr.. w. Hyatt, had his right hand blown
off and was otherways much injured in face and
body, by the powder, the oher, Tarrans Brady,
was more dangerously injured, having the from
tai hone of his head shattered considerably; one
eve blown out, and his face and neck tlreadfuly
mangletl-but little hopes are entertained of his
recovery The fractured part Of Mr.. Ilyatt's
arm was amputated, and hop are entertained
that he will do well.


This morning our Philadelphia friends were
escorted to the steamboat Superior, On hoard of
which they embarked to return to their native
city, bearing with them the warmest wishes Of
our citizens, for safe passage. Capt. Cooper's
Company was composed Of fine looking young
men, handsomely uniformed and well discipln-
ed, and their department whilst with rs was
such as to engage our warnest feelings of re-
spect and admiration. Less cannot be said Of
our own troops; young, vigorous and full Of mar.
tial pride, they cndcavorcd to excel in this, to
its admirers, fascinating sciences and so great is
their improvement in.discipline, that one would
suppose they had been, instead of u few weeks
rgidly drilled for years Their general appear
ance is highly creditable.

full articles.headline: From he F1tMa.lph:u Faiaa.nm.
full articles.article:
A case of novelty and extraordinary interest
occupied the Mayors Court all Thursday last. -
Thomas Clark, a young man OF handsome APP
pearance, about "a years ofaSe, lis hair and face
looking especially sleek and smooth, by occu-
patton shoemaker, and by profession fanatic,
was tried under on old act Of Assembly, for
speaking wilf,llly, dcspitetnly, and lsrespcct-
fully of the Almighty. The Indictment charg-
cs him with saying and repeating at divers times
and places, 81 AN Godt"


1t tappearcd that Clark profcsscd a smattcr ng
of the school OF Toannas Snuthcote and Jcmima
Wilkinson, representing himself to be divine,
not in his origin, but in his nilsson and powers.
lie has been for months surround d in this city
by forty or fifty women and delldcl men, who
are fools enough to believe hi, pleposterous pro-
fcssions These he classiics as his disciples, and
gives to them all his pretended powers They
believe him to possess the faculty Of working
miracles, and many of them s~ore in open court,
that he had actually performed them; such as
making the dumb to speak; the sick well; and
the Blind TO sec. CLARK and his followers call
themselves .erastcrs." Clark himself has been
for some time generally known among the idle
bows of his vicinity, as 1om Cldrk


Judge Read charged the jury to acqnit for
want Of wilful malice. that Clark was weak
foolish fanatic, doing all he did nnocently, and
being more misguided and silly than criminal
more an object Of pity than punishment.


Clark addressed the court and jury for long
time. lie had the scriptures in his hand, from
which he quoted willy and copously. His
speech was little else than citations otpassaSes.
Verdict ofacqutal.

!, sheIter Of any kind, exposed to the sun,
aiads oal Is and repeated showers. But such ex-
N'ns a.,,rs Is to their condition nothing novel
M pohit has taught them to bear with apathy
,hs !" pelting Of the pitilcss storm" = York

full articles.headline: From The Conaecticut Mirror.
full articles.article:
few miles and is told in plain language, as one
whose scene is laid afar off, and whose indict-
ments are described in a Scotch or an Irish dla-
lect' This last week, married woman in the
neighbering town Of ---, who had been
working I'M onfactory, missed, some hour or
so after sunset her lit,lc boy of about four years
old How long he had been gone could not be
told, for the woman had been hard at work all
the afternoon, and all others were too busy to
care for her or her child Her first search was
silent and alonc-hopiny to find him, and disk
ing 10 communicate mothers a?prchcnsions to
the other males and females of the cotton f-cto-
ry. The night grew very dark and the search
very hopeless, and resort was finally had to all
the men, women and children of the establish
mcnt, TO help her to find her boy. The build
ings, with all their sluiccs, wheels, bands buck
les, were searched with an awful apprehension
on the mother. and on the part OTHER assistant a
| yct more horrible though undcEnal,le hnpc, 1--WE
will out with the word though il shame human
nat,irc) of finding leg or an arm among some
! part of the machinery. Nothing, not even a
curl of his hair, was to be found on the well ex-
amned cogs. I.antherns were in vain carried
| in nice and minute search round all the premls-
es. Wordsworth, who SO truly to nature de-
cribes the loss of Lucy Gray,


"1hc sweetest thing that ever grew
| Beside human door"


could tell Of the agony Of the parent, and the
more useful because less agitated cxertions ot
her fellow laborcrs. But we will leave him and
return to the factory. Some one, when all 9TH
cr aid seemed to fail, proposed to ring the Fac
tory hell. ssit might he said sget more help,
and nirht awake the child who might be sleep
ing somewhere and might somehow be walked
up-at anv rate it could do no harm, and be-
sides there was nothing else they could do. =
The lantherns and the factory bell in the night,


aroused all the bells in the ncighborhooti, and


all the inhabitants of the contiguous e''y. me


cry Of fire and of swhere is it, was raised at
once.-Down came the engines--dewn came the


people, and best of all, down came the Fire


Warlens.


Joab Stark, hard working man i'll the day


time, and proportionaby hard sleeping man IN


the night, had heard nothing Of all this disturb
ance. though he lodged in the factory buildings,
and though they had been ransacked from ridge


pole to foundation, until he was aroused BY the


voice of an energetic Fircwardcn, who Tor once,


did not exactly know what he was about, with


the plain and intelgble command, 'torm q


line. !" At which he awoke, and inquired what


was the matter The warden couldn't tell him,


but the mother could--"she had lost her child


She said. .sher little Jim that he used TO play


with. and she couldn't find him and the Engines
had nothing TO do with it." "All firclock, P" said


Toab, "I went out on an errand this afternoon TO


the paper mills, and see Jim at Squire iiin


IIancock ocks-he'd run away, and he was too urea
to walk back, and | thought he'd better stay


there and I'd come back and tell the folks where
he was-and when come baca forgot sill about


it,"


S,eam Cayriace.-An extraordinary sensation
: was created on Thursday evening, IN the ncign-
borhood of the Regents Park, by the sudden


appearance Of (iuerney's newly invented steam
, carriage, or selfmovng machine, winch coursea


round part of the new road up the ascent OF the


Albany road, at the rate of ten miles an hour,
/. carving several persons inside and behind 1t


seemed to move with the most perfect ease, and
: without any appearance OF smoke whatever.-


The condt.cfeur evidently held the carriage tin-
/ der complete command; and whenever the crowd


which gathered about it became troublesome,
shooting away from them with speed equal to
that of a mail coach.--London O6Serrer.
Mr.. Duponceau, Of Philadelphia, has pub


lshed note, correcting the report which
is now circulating throughout the country,
that he had succeeded to the place lett va

A friend relates to us the following instance of
canine sagacity; Mr.. Joseph Hanson resides on
the Pinkham road in the county of Coos, near
Mount Washington, eight miles from any inhab-
liant. Ills child was lately taken dangerously
sck--so that neither himself nor his wife could
safely leave without assistance. Enclosing a
letter in a packet, he despatched his dog ten
miles to the house Of Mr.. Pinkham; and the dog
delivered the message in an hour and half, so
that in the course Of few hoursthc necessary as.
sistance arrived When the dog arrived at Ad-
ans among the inhabitants, he passed several
persons, and cvaded them, as if fearful that he
should be prevented from doing his duty.

A gentleman from Southington has furnished
us with the particulars of an accident, the reci-
al which will, we trust, operate as a salutary
caution TO parents, while it awakens the deepest
feelings Of sympathy for the distressed mother.
On Sunday, the 18th ult little child besought
its mother for knife; after some importantly,
she allowed it to take the instrument. The
child then begged to have it opened; the moth.
er mprudenty opened it, and passed out of the
room, In moment, she heard her infant cream
returned ard b held it corpse! The knife
was sharp pointed, and the child stumbled and
fell upon it with such force, that it entered the
left side, and pierced the heart.

The following anecdotc is given il Par


is paper, as received from country cores
pondeni:.-About twenty years ago young
man, violently in loye with young Provin-
cial, not being able to obtain the consent Of
her family to their union, he enlisted as
soldier. In the campaign of 1921, he was
taken prisoner by the Russians. and sent in
to Siberia, whence he escaped, and joined
horde of 'rartars, then at war with China
He was second time made prisoner; but,
more fortunate than in his first captivity, he
insinuated himself into the good graces OF
his conquerors, and gradually rose to the
dignity of a Mandarin. His affection .did not
however change with his good fortune; he
despatched vessel to Europe to convey the
object Of his first love to China; this vessel
has lust arrived at Marseiles. and will re-
turn as soon as the object of its mission shall
have been executed.

FROM LAGUlRA.-A slip from the
New York Mercantile, says-We learn by
the Eclipse, which left Lagura on the 9th
inst, that Bolivar remained at Caracas, and
Il vas not known when he would depart tor
the interior.
"A letter from Laguira, of the Sd, says.
ave have intelligence, that by direction OF
the executive, all the guns and ammunition
in the different forts of Porto Cavelo, have
been removed, and that the only castle now
remaining i'll that place. is to be demolish- :
ed. The object of these proceedings is quite
unknown to us. 1t is reported here. that the
Congress has accepted the resignation Of
Bolivar.


The following extract is from Mr.. Bddle's
culogium on Jefferson -


"Thrre lies in the depths of every heart
that dream of youth, and the chastened WISH
of manhood, which neither cares nor hon
ors can ever extinguish, the hope OF one day
resting from the pursuits which aosoro US;
OF interposing between our old age and the
tomb-soine tranquil interval of refiect'on'
when with feelings not subdued but soften
ed, with passions not exhausted but mel
lowed. we may look calmly on the past with
out regret, and ON the future without appre-
hension. But in the tumult OF the world
this vision for ever recedes as we approach
it; the passions which have asitated oui
